sen.j: 縁起物（えんぎもの）とは、よい事があるようにと祝い祈るための品物。
sen.e: A lucky charm is an object with which to celebrate or pray for something good.
Engimono (a lucky charm) is an object with which to celebrate or pray for something good.
Engimono (a lucky charm) is an object with which to celebrate or pray for something good.

sen.j: 五穀豊穣、大漁追福、商売繁盛、家内安全、無病息災、安寧長寿、夫婦円満、子孫繁栄、祖先崇拝や招福祈願、厄除祈念や「ハレとケ｛天気ではなく天晴れ（あっぱれ）や晴れ晴れとした気持ちの「晴れ」をさす｝」に纏わる物など多岐に渡る。
sen.e: There is so wide a variety of Engimono, including those to pray for huge harvest (of cereals), good catch and memorial service, prosperous trade, safety of the family, a state of perfect health, peace and longevity, a harmonious marriage, fertility and family prosperity, ancestor worship, good luck and protection from evil, as well as those concerning "hare"(which means "appare"(splendid) or a good mood, not fine weather) and "ke".

There is so wide a variety of Engimono, including those to pray for huge harvest (of cereals), good catch and memorial service, prosperous business, safety of the family, a state of perfect health, peace and longevity, a harmonious marriage, fertility and family prosperity, ancestor worship, good luck and protection from evil, as well as those concerning 'hare to ke' (which means 'appare' [splendid] or a good mood, not fine weather).
sen.cmt: 表記などを変えました。
sen.e: There is so wide a variety of Engimono, including those to pray for huge harvest (of cereals), good catch and memorial service, prosperous business, safety of the family, a state of perfect health, peace and longevity, a harmonious marriage, fertility and family prosperity, ancestor worship, good luck and protection from evil, as well as those concerning 'hare to ke' (which means 'appare' [splendid] or a good mood, not fine weather).

sen.j: また、祭礼や縁日や市などの寺社の参道や境内や門前町・鳥居前町において参詣者に授与・販売する歴史的、文化的背景のあるものを指す。
sen.e: Engimono also means something to be sold or offered to visitors at sando (an approach to the temple), temple grounds, Monzen-machi (a temple town) and Toriimae-machi (town in front of torii (Shinto shrine archway)) on the day of festivals and fairs, based on the historical or cultural backgrounds.

Engimono also means something to be sold or offered to visitors at sando (an approach to the temple), temple or shrine grounds, Monzen-machi (a temple town) and Toriimae-machi (town in front of torii [Shinto shrine archway]) on the day of festivals and fairs, based on the historical and cultural backgrounds.

Engimono also means something to be sold or offered to visitors at sando (an approach to the temple), temple or shrine grounds, Monzen-machi (a temple town) and Toriimae-machi (town in front of torii [Shinto shrine archway]) on the day of festivals and fairs, based on the historical and cultural backgrounds.

sen.j: 日本古来の物として特殊な例としては祭りなどで選ばれた福男やなまはげなどの演者、大相撲など神の依り代になった人も縁起物とされる。
sen.e: Special examples peculiar to Japan include fukuotoko (the luckiest man) selected in a festival, performers such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year) and people who become yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) in events such as the ground sumo tournament.

Special examples peculiar to Japan include fukuotoko (the luckiest man) selected in a festival, performers such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year) and people who become yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) in events such as the ground sumo tournament.

Special examples peculiar to Japan include fukuotoko (the luckiest man) selected in a festival, performers such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year) and people who become yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) in events such as the ground sumo tournament.

sen.j: 時節による滋養強壮の目的で長寿や薬事効果を期待して食された物として鰻や初鰹なども縁起物といえる。
sen.e: Eel and hatsugatsuo (the season's first bonito) are also included in Engimono, because they are eaten for the purpose of nutritional fortification according to seasons as well as in the hope of obtaining longevity and medical effects.

Eel and hatsugatsuo (the season's first bonito) are also included in Engimono, because they are eaten for the purpose of nutritional fortification according to seasons as well as in the hope of obtaining longevity and medical effects.

Eel and hatsugatsuo (the season's first bonito) are also included in Engimono, because they are eaten for the purpose of nutritional fortification according to seasons as well as in the hope of obtaining longevity and medical effects.

sen.j: 仏教、密教、ヒンドゥー教などのインド文化を起源とするものや五節句や二十四節気など中華文明の風俗習慣を起源に持つ物も存在し、それらが日本古来の神道と渾然一体となっているものもある。
sen.e: Some are derived from Indian culture such as Buddhism, Esoteric Buddhism and Hinduism, some originates from manners and customs of civilization in China such as five seasonal festivals and Nijushisekki (24 divisions of the old calendar), and in some cases Indian and Chinese elements have been blended together with the Japanese traditional Shinto.

Some are derived from Indian culture such as Buddhism, Esoteric Buddhism and Hinduism, some originates from manners and customs of civilization in China such as five seasonal festivals and Nijushisekki (24 divisions of the old calendar), and in some cases these elements have been blended together with the Japanese traditional Shinto.

Some are derived from Indian culture such as Buddhism, Esoteric Buddhism and Hinduism, some originates from manners and customs of civilization in China such as five seasonal festivals and Nijushisekki (24 divisions of the old calendar), and in some cases these elements have been blended together with the Japanese traditional Shinto.

sen.j: （具体的には七福神の一柱である「大黒」はヒンドゥー教を起源とし、日本には大乗仏教の「大黒天」と、密教の「大黒天」と、神道の神である大国主命と仏教の大黒天が神仏習合した「大黒様」と、三つの神仏が存在し姿も意味合いもそれぞれ違うものである。）
sen.e: (Concretely speaking, Daikoku (god of wealth), one of the Seven Deities of Good Luck, originates from Hinduism, and in Japan there are three kinds of Daikoku which differ in form and implication: "Daikokuten" of Mahayana Buddhism, "Daikokuten" of Esoteric Buddhism and "Daikoku-sama" created through syncretization of Okuninushi no Mikoto (a Shinto deity) with Daikokuten of Buddhism.

(Concretely speaking, 'Daikoku' (god of wealth), one of the Seven Deities of Good Luck, originates from Hinduism, and in Japan there are three kinds of Daikoku which differ in form and implication: 'Daikokuten' of Mahayana Buddhism, 'Daikokuten' of Esoteric Buddhism and 'Daikoku-sama' created through syncretization of Okuninushi no Mikoto (a Shinto deity) with Daikokuten of Buddhism.)

(Concretely speaking, 'Daikoku' (god of wealth), one of the Seven Deities of Good Luck, originates from Hinduism, and in Japan there are three kinds of Daikoku which differ in form and implication: 'Daikokuten' of Mahayana Buddhism, 'Daikokuten' of Esoteric Buddhism and 'Daikoku-sama' created through syncretization of Okuninushi no Mikoto (a Shinto deity) with Daikokuten of Buddhism.)

tit.j: 社寺、境内などで参詣人に販売・授与する物
tit.e: something to be sold or offered to visitors in temples, shrines and their grounds
Something to be sold or offered to visitors in temples, shrines and their grounds
Something to be sold or offered to visitors in temples, shrines and their grounds

sen.j: 別名「牽牛」（花は「牽牛花」）というが、これは、その種（牽牛子）が薬として非常に高価で珍重されたため、種を贈られた者はウシを牽いて御礼をしたという、古い中国の謂れである。
sen.e: It is also known as "kengyu (Cowherd)", and its flower is sometimes called "kengyuka"because in ancient China its seeds (called "kengoshi") were so expensive and so valuable medicines that people who were given the seeds would thank the giver taking their cows with them.

It is also known as 'kengyu' (Cowherd) (its flower is called 'kengyuka') because in ancient China its seeds (called kengoshi) were so expensive and so valuable medicines that people who were given the seeds would thank the giver taking their cows with them.

It is also known as 'kengyu' (Cowherd) (its flower is called 'kengyuka') because in ancient China its seeds (called kengoshi) were so expensive and so valuable medicines that people who were given the seeds would thank the giver taking their cows with them.

sen.j: 平安時代に日本にも伝わり、牽牛子は百薬の長として珍重された。
sen.e: It was introduced in Japan in the Heian period, and kengoshi was highly valued as the chief of all medicine since then.
It was introduced to Japan in the Heian period, and kengoshi was highly valued as the chief of all medicine since then.
It was introduced to Japan in the Heian period, and kengoshi was highly valued as the chief of all medicine since then.

sen.j: その後江戸時代には、牽牛との逢瀬を願う織女になぞらえて「朝顔姫」などと呼ぶことが一般的になった。
sen.e: Later, in the Edo period, it was generally called "Asaga-hime (Morning Glory Princess)," compared to the Weaver longing to see the Cowherd.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Later, in the Edo period, it was generally called 'Asagao-hime' (Morning Glory Princess), compared to the Weaver longing to see the Cowherd.
sen.cmt: スペル、表記を変えました。
sen.e: Later, in the Edo period, it was generally called 'Asagao-hime' (Morning Glory Princess), compared to the Weaver longing to see the Cowherd.

sen.j: 花が咲いた朝顔は「彦星」と「織姫星」が今年も出会えたしるしとして、縁起の良いものとされた。
sen.e: Morning glory in bloom was regarded as a kind of lucky charm, because people believed that it was a sign that the "Cowherd star" and the "Weaver star" could see each other again that year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: お盆の起源は仏教に由来する盂蘭盆会であるが、日本では古来の先祖崇拝や精霊崇拝の要素を取り込んで、現在のいわゆる「お盆」の形になった。
sen.e: The origin of the Obon festival is the Urabon-e festival originated in Buddhism, but in Japan ancient ancestor worship and spirit worship have combined to make the style of the Obon festival into what it is now.

The origin of the Obon festival is the Urabon-e festival originated in Buddhism, but in Japan, it became the current style of 'Obon festival' incorporating ancient ancestor worship and spirit worship.

The origin of the Obon festival is the Urabon-e festival originated in Buddhism, but in Japan, it became the current style of 'Obon festival' incorporating ancient ancestor worship and spirit worship.

sen.j: ほおずきは漢字で「鬼灯」と書き、先祖の霊（「鬼」の字義のひとつ）が迷わず帰ってこられるように導く灯りの象徴として、精霊棚に供えられる。
sen.e: The kanji (Chinese characters) for hozuki literally means "Oni's light," and ground cherries are offered on the Shoryodana (shelf placed ancestral tablet and altarage in the Bon festival) as a symbol of lights leading ancestors' souls (which are also indicated by kanji "Oni") safely back to their home.

As hozuki is written '鬼灯' (ogre's light) in kanji characters, it is offered on the Shoryodana (shelf placed ancestral tablet and altarage in the Obon festival) as a symbol of lights leading ancestors' souls (one of the meaning of '鬼' [ogre]) safely back to their home.
sen.cmt: 漢字の字義の説明なので、漢字を補足して表現を変えました。
sen.e: As hozuki is written '鬼灯' (ogre's light) in kanji characters, it is offered on the Shoryodana (shelf placed ancestral tablet and altarage in the Obon festival) as a symbol of lights leading ancestors' souls (one of the meaning of '鬼' [ogre]) safely back to their home.

sen.e: It is attached to the part of the wooden framework of a roof called "tsuka" after raising the framework at the time of a Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony).

sen.j: 家や家族の様々な幸福や厄除けを願う物であり、角材に祝上棟などと書き込み紅白の古式折り紙や紙製の扇、金箔や銀箔またはそれらに代わる金、銀紙などで装飾された物。
sen.e: It is square timber with words "celebration for roof-laying" written on it, decorated with old style origami in red and white, a paper fan, and gold or silver leaves or their substitute (gold or silver paper), and is used to pray for various forms of happiness and protection against evils, in connection with the house and the family.

It is square timber inscribed with the words such as celebration for roof-laying, decorated with old style origami in red and white, a paper fan, gold and silver leaves or their substitute (gold or silver paper), and is used to pray for various forms of happiness and protection against evils, in connection with the house and the family.

sen.j: 古来アワビは百年生きると考えられており、そのアワビ干物にして、紐状に途切れることなくきった物をさらに長く伸ばすことから長寿を願った。
sen.e: In order to pray for long life, abalones, which have been traditionally thought to live for a hundred years, are dried, cut into unbroken strings and further stretched long.

sen.j: - 子生婦とも表記し子孫繁栄を表す。
sen.e: One of the kanji pairs for kelp literally means "a woman who gives birth to a child," so it symbolizes fertility.
It is written as 子生婦 (literally, "a woman who gives birth to a child") and symbolizes fertility.

sen.j: - 白髪に見立て末永く夫婦円満という意味。
sen.e: As they are associated with white hair, they symbolize a long-lasting harmonious marriage.
As they are associated with white hair, they symbolize a long-lasting harmonious marriage.

sen.j: - 関西では目録は品に含まれずその代わりに指輪が入る。

sen.j: - 柳樽ともいい家内喜多留と書く。
sen.e: It is also called yanagidaru, and one of the combinations of kanji for yanagidaru literally means "A lot of pleasures stay within the house."
It is also called yanagidaru, and written as 家内喜多留 (literally, "A lot of pleasures stay within the house").
It is also called yanagidaru, and written as 家内喜多留 (literally, "A lot of pleasures stay within the house").

sen.j: - 古くから富士山は神道による霊峰とされており江戸時代にはその「霊験あらたか」に肖ろう（あやかろう）と庶民が挙って（こぞって）富士詣（ふじもうで）を行った。
sen.e: Traditionally Mt. Fuji was regarded as a sacred mountain in Shinto, and everybody visited the mountain in the hope of capitalizing its remarkably miraculous efficacy in the Edo period.
Traditionally Mt. Fuji was regarded as a sacred mountain in Shinto, and everybody visited the mountain in the hope of capitalizing its 'remarkably miraculous efficacy' in the Edo period.
Traditionally Mt. Fuji was regarded as a sacred mountain in Shinto, and everybody visited the mountain in the hope of capitalizing its 'remarkably miraculous efficacy' in the Edo period.

sen.j: 様々な理由で富士詣が出来ない人々のために神社などにおいて富士塚と呼ばれる縮小版の富士山に見立てた小山が作られ、頂上には実際と同じく鳥居や祠などが設けられた。
sen.e: For the sake of those who could not visit Mt. Fuji for various reasons, a mound of dirt called "Fujizuka," a miniature of Mt. Fuji, was made in shrines, and torii and hokora (a small shrine) were built on top of the Fujizuka Mound, just as on the actual mountain.

For the sake of those who could not visit Mt. Fuji for various reasons, a mound of dirt called Fujizuka, a miniature of Mt. Fuji, was made in shrines, and so on, and torii and hokora (a small shrine) were built on top of the Fujizuka Mound, just as on the actual mountain.

For the sake of those who could not visit Mt. Fuji for various reasons, a mound of dirt called Fujizuka, a miniature of Mt. Fuji, was made in shrines, and so on, and torii and hokora (a small shrine) were built on top of the Fujizuka Mound, just as on the actual mountain.

sen.j: またこの富士信仰から富士見という地名が富士山を望める日本各地に残されている。
sen.e: Furthermore, these beliefs about Mt. Fuji have left a place-name "Fujimi" in various places in Japan where you command a fine view of Mt. Fuji.
Furthermore, these beliefs about Mt. Fuji have left a place-name Fujimi in various places in Japan where you command a fine view of Mt. Fuji.
Furthermore, these beliefs about Mt. Fuji have left a place-name Fujimi in various places in Japan where you command a fine view of Mt. Fuji.

sen.j: 古くは宮廷で公家が薬事効果を期待し食していたが、戦国時代 (日本)には鯨呑が「国を飲み込んで併合・吸収合併する」と言う意味や鯨波の声｛鬨の声（ときのこえ）と読み意味も同じ｝が「戦いに勝つ」という意味や鯨吼が「轟き渡る」という意味などから武将に好まれ武家の間でも珍重された。
sen.e: In ancient times, people from imperial families ate whale meat in the Imperial court, looking forward to medical effects, but later in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) whale meat was loved by busho (Japanese military commander) and highly valued by samurai families, for geidon (a swallow by a whale) means "annexation of another country," tokinokoe (toki can be expressed by a pair of kanji meaning "a whale's wave") is associated with a victory, and geikou (a whale's outcry) means "booming out."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In ancient times, people from imperial families ate whale meat in the Imperial Court, expecting medical effects, but later in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) whale meat was loved by busho (Japanese military commander) and highly valued by samurai families, for geidon (a swallow by a whale) means 'annexation of another country,' toki no koe (toki can be expressed by a pair of kanji meaning, a whale's wave, and toki (鯨波) sometimes written as 鬨 in Chinese character) is associated with a victory, and geiko (a whale's outcry) means 'booming out.'

In ancient times, people from imperial families ate whale meat in the Imperial Court, expecting medical effects, but later in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) whale meat was loved by busho (Japanese military commander) and highly valued by samurai families, for geidon (a swallow by a whale) means 'annexation of another country,' toki no koe (toki can be expressed by a pair of kanji meaning, a whale's wave, and toki (鯨波) sometimes written as 鬨 in Chinese character) is associated with a victory, and geiko (a whale's outcry) means 'booming out.'

sen.j: 江戸時代には捕鯨の隆盛と共に庶民の縁起物として広く節気などに食されるようになった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, with flourishing of whale hunt, whale meat became a popular lucky charm for ordinary people and was eaten at sekki (24 divisions of the solar year).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period, with flourishing of whale hunt, whale meat became a popular lucky charm for ordinary people and was eaten at sekki.
sen.cmt: 前出補足を削除しました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, with flourishing of whale hunt, whale meat became a popular lucky charm for ordinary people and was eaten at sekki.

Kanreki (the celebration of a person's 60th birthday), Kiju (77th birthday), Sanju (80th birthday), Hanju (81st birthday), Beiju (88th birthday), Sotsuju (90th birthday), Hakuju (99th birthday), Hyakuju (100th birthday), Chaju (108th birthday), Dai Kanreki (120th birthday) and Tenju (250th birthday).

Kanreki (the celebration of a person's 60th birthday), Kiju (77th birthday), Sanju (80th birthday), Hanju (81st birthday), Beiju (88th birthday), Sotsuju (90th birthday), Hakuju (99th birthday), Hyakuju (100th birthday), Chaju (108th birthday), Dai Kanreki (120th birthday) and Tenju (250th birthday).

Kanreki (the celebration of a person's 60th birthday), Kiju (77th birthday), Sanju (80th birthday), Hanju (81st birthday), Beiju (88th birthday), Sotsuju (90th birthday), Hakuju (99th birthday), Hyakuju (100th birthday), Chaju (108th birthday), Dai Kanreki (120th birthday) and Tenju (250th birthday).

sen.j: - 初日の出や富士山の山頂から望む行為に代表され、世界的には夕日を愛でる習慣が多い中、日本独特ともいわれる朝日信仰（太陽信仰）である。
sen.e: The sunrise belief (sun belief), represented by an act of watching hatsu hinode (first sunrise of New year) or watching a sunrise from the top of Mt. Fuji, is said to be peculiar to Japan, while there are a lot of practices of admiring the setting sun all over the world.

The sunrise belief (sun belief), represented by an act of watching hatsu hinode (first sunrise of New year) or watching a sunrise from the top of Mt. Fuji, is said to be peculiar to Japan, while there are a lot of practices of admiring the setting sun all over the world.
sen.cmt: スペース削除などしました。
sen.e: The sunrise belief (sun belief), represented by an act of watching hatsu hinode (first sunrise of New year) or watching a sunrise from the top of Mt. Fuji, is said to be peculiar to Japan, while there are a lot of practices of admiring the setting sun all over the world.

sen.j: 「日出ずる国（ひいずるくに）」や「日本（ひのもと）」が美称であることや「天晴れ（あっぱれ）」または「早起き」が美徳であることからもその思いが窺える。
sen.e: This sunrise belief is expressed in the facts that expressions such as "Hi-Izuru-Kuni "(Land of the Rising Sun) and "Hinomoto" are praises, and that "Appare" and "early rising" are something to be respected.

This sunrise belief is expressed in the facts that expressions such as 'Hi Izuru Kuni' (Land of the Rising Sun) and 'Hinomoto' (place where the sun rises) are praises, and that 'Appare' (splendid) and 'early rising' are something to be respected.

This sunrise belief is expressed in the facts that expressions such as 'Hi Izuru Kuni' (Land of the Rising Sun) and 'Hinomoto' (place where the sun rises) are praises, and that 'Appare' (splendid) and 'early rising' are something to be respected.

sen.e: expressions such as Kodakara (the treasure that is children) and doji (child), embodiment of fertility, family prosperity and part of Rinne Tensho (all things being in flux through the endless circle of birth, death, and rebirth, the circle of transmigration), and specifically "red chanchanko" (red padded sleeveless kimono jacket, red Japanese vest) worn at the celebration of Kanreki

There are expressions such as Kodakara (the treasure that is children) and doji (child), embodiment of fertility, family prosperity and part of Rinne Tensho (all things being in flux through the endless circle of birth, death, and rebirth, the circle of transmigration); for example, 'red chanchanko' (red padded sleeveless kimono jacket, red Japanese vest) worn at the celebration of Kanreki.

There are expressions such as Kodakara (the treasure that is children) and doji (child), embodiment of fertility, family prosperity and part of Rinne Tensho (all things being in flux through the endless circle of birth, death, and rebirth, the circle of transmigration); for example, 'red chanchanko' (red padded sleeveless kimono jacket, red Japanese vest) worn at the celebration of Kanreki.

Oban (a large-sized old Japanese gold coin) and Koban (a small-sized coin)

sen.j: 日本においては釣竿と釣針（弓矢も同様）は古くは狩りとしての使用から「サチ（幸）」といい「サ」は箭（矢）の古い読みで矢や釣り針を意味し、「チ」は霊威を示した。
sen.e: In Japan, a fishing rod and a fishhook (and a bow and an arrow as well) were traditionally called "Sachi" based on their usage in hunting, because "sa," an old name for an arrow, meant an arrow or a fishhook and "chi" meant a charisma.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Japan, a fishing rod and a fishhook (and a bow and an arrow as well) were traditionally called 'Sachi' (chase) based on their usage in hunting, because 'sa,' an old name for an arrow, meant an arrow or a fishhook and 'chi' meant a charisma.

In Japan, a fishing rod and a fishhook (and a bow and an arrow as well) were traditionally called 'Sachi' (chase) based on their usage in hunting, because 'sa,' an old name for an arrow, meant an arrow or a fishhook and 'chi' meant a charisma.

sen.j: 釣竿と釣針・弓矢は霊力を持つ狩猟具であった。
sen.e: Fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows were hunting appliances with psychic powers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows were hunting equipments with psychic powers.
Fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows were hunting equipments with psychic powers.

sen.j: また恵比寿が携える狩猟具としても知られる。
sen.e: In addition, they are known as hunting appliances carried by Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce).
In addition, they are known as hunting equipments carried by Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce).
In addition, they are known as hunting equipments carried by Ebisu (god of fishing and commerce).

sen.j: - 山幸彦は昔話としても広く知られる弓矢を用いる狩りの神。
sen.e: Yamasachihiko is the god of hunting who used a bow and arrows, who are well-known in folk stories.
Yamasachihiko is the god of hunting who used a bow and arrows, who are well-known in folk stories.
Yamasachihiko is the god of hunting who used a bow and arrows, who are well-known in folk stories.

sen.j: 「幸（さち）」が「弓矢・釣竿と釣針」を示したり、狩りの獲物や漁の獲物を指す「山の幸・海の幸」を表す謂れとなる物語の海幸彦と並ぶ主人公である。
sen.e: He and Umisachihiko are the central characters of the story which showed that "Sachi" meant "fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows," and which resulted in expressions such as "Yama-no Sachi" and "Umi-no Sachi"meaning the prey of hunting or fishing.

He and Umisachihiko are the central characters of the story which showed that 'Sachi' meant 'fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows,' and which resulted in expressions such as 'Yama no Sachi' and 'Umi no Sachi' meaning the prey of hunting or fishing respectively.

He and Umisachihiko are the central characters of the story which showed that 'Sachi' meant 'fishing rods, hooks, bows and arrows,' and which resulted in expressions such as 'Yama no Sachi' and 'Umi no Sachi' meaning the prey of hunting or fishing respectively.
matsuriya (festival arrow) and matsuri yumi (festival bow)
Matsuriya (festival arrow) and matsuri yumi (festival bow):
Matsuriya (festival arrow) and matsuri yumi (festival bow):

sen.j: - 五穀豊穣を願い行われる日本各地にのこる神事であり祭り。
sen.e: a Shinto ritual and festival conducted in the hope of obtaining huge harvest (of cereals), which remains in various regions of Japan
A Shinto ritual and festival conducted in the hope of obtaining huge harvest (of cereals), which remains in various regions of Japan.
A Shinto ritual and festival conducted in the hope of obtaining huge harvest (of cereals), which remains in various regions of Japan.

sen.j: - 祭り矢・祭り弓を起源とし、江戸時代には市や縁日が立つ参道や境内、門前町で出店や夜店として、弓矢を使い的に当て、的の位置や種類により、商品や賞金が振舞われ、庶民はこれを縁起担ぎとして楽しんだ。
sen.e: It originates from matsuriya and matsuriyumi, for in the Edo period common people enjoyed, as superstition, aiming at targets with a bow and arrows and were given prizes and prize money according to the position and type of targets, on Sando where a fair or festival was held and at stands and yomise (night stall) in temple grounds and Monzen-machi.

It originates from matsuriya and matsuriyumi, for in the Edo period common people enjoyed, as superstition, aiming at targets with a bow and arrows and were given prizes and prize money according to the position and type of targets on an approach to the temple where a fair or festival was held and at stands and yomise (night stall) in temple grounds and Monzen-machi.

It originates from matsuriya and matsuriyumi, for in the Edo period common people enjoyed, as superstition, aiming at targets with a bow and arrows and were given prizes and prize money according to the position and type of targets on an approach to the temple where a fair or festival was held and at stands and yomise (night stall) in temple grounds and Monzen-machi.

sen.j: 大晦日に朝廷で行われた追儺（ついな）の式で、鬼を祓う為に使われた弓矢の事で、それぞれ葦（アシ）の茎と桃の木で出来ていた。
sen.e: They were used to purify evils at tsuina no shiki (ceremony of driving out evil spirits) conducted in the Imperial court on New Year's Eve, and made from reed stalk and peach tree.
They were used to purify evils at tsuina no shiki (ceremony of driving out evil spirits) conducted in the Imperial Court on New Year's Eve, and made from reed stalk and peach tree.
They were used to purify evils at tsuina no shiki (ceremony of driving out evil spirits) conducted in the Imperial Court on New Year's Eve, and made from reed stalk and peach tree.

sen.j: - はじまりは正月に行われたその年の吉凶占いに使う弓矢。
sen.e: They originate from a bow and an arrow used for fortune-telling of the year conducted on New Year's Day.
They originate from a bow and an arrow used for fortune-telling of the year conducted on New Year's Day.
They originate from a bow and an arrow used for fortune-telling of the year conducted on New Year's Day.

sen.j: 後に、家内安全を祈願する幣串と同じように、家の鬼を祓う魔除けとして上棟式に小屋組に奉納される神祭具の事で、近年では破魔矢・破魔弓ともに神社などの厄除けの縁起物として知られる。
sen.e: Later they became shinsaigu (equipment used in rituals) which were dedicated in koyagumi (roof truss or framework) at the time of Jotoshiki as an amulet against Devils, just like heigoshi used to pray for safety of the family, and these days, along with hamaya and hamayumi, they are known as lucky charm against evils offered in shrines.

Later they became shinsaigu (equipment used in rituals) which were dedicated in koyagumi (roof truss or framework) at the time of Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony) as an amulet against Devils, just like heigoshi used to pray for safety of the family, and these days, along with hamaya and hamayumi, they are known as lucky charm against evils offered in shrines.
sen.cmt: 前出補足を削除しました。
sen.e: Later they became shinsaigu (equipment used in rituals) which were dedicated in koyagumi (roof truss or framework) at the time of Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony) as an amulet against Devils, just like heigoshi used to pray for safety of the family, and these days, along with hamaya and hamayumi, they are known as lucky charm against evils offered in shrines.

sen.j: 蓬矢（ほうし）・桑弓（そうきゅう）
- それぞれ、蓬の矢（よもぎのや）・桑の弓（くわのゆみ）とも言い、男の子が生まれた時に前途の厄を払うため、家の四方に向かって桑の弓で蓬の矢を射た。
sen.e: When a baby boy was born, mugwort arrows were shot in four directions of the house with a mulberry bow in order to purify evils in future.
When a baby boy was born, mugwort arrows were shot in four directions of the house with a mulberry bow in order to purify evils in future.
When a baby boy was born, mugwort arrows were shot in four directions of the house with a mulberry bow in order to purify evils in future.

sen.j: 桑の弓は桑の木で作った弓、蓬の矢は蓬の葉で羽を矧いだ（はいだ）矢。
sen.e: A mulberry bow is made from mulberry tree, and a mugwort arrow is made of feather pared with the use of mugwort leaves.
A mulberry bow is made from mulberry tree, and a mugwort arrow is made of feather pared with the use of mugwort leaves.
A mulberry bow is made from mulberry tree, and a mugwort arrow is made of feather pared with the use of mugwort leaves.

sen.j: - 鳴弦とも言い、弓 (武器)の弦を引いて鳴らす事により悪霊や魔や穢れを祓う行為。
sen.e: It is called "meigen" (resounding bowstrings), an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.
It is called meigen (resounding bowstrings), an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.
It is called meigen (resounding bowstrings), an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.

sen.j: 弓鳴らし・弦打ちともいう。
sen.e: It is also referred to as yuminarashi or genuchi.
It is also referred to as yuminarashi or genuchi.
It is also referred to as yuminarashi or genuchi.

sen.j: - 反抗や謀反（むほん）や楯突くことであるが、本来は鳴弦のことで弓の弦を引いて鳴らす事により悪霊や魔や穢れを祓う行為。
sen.e: It is an idiom meaning disobedience, rebellion and defiance, but originally it meant meigen, an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.
It is an idiom meaning disobedience, rebellion and defiance, but originally it meant meigen, an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.
It is an idiom meaning disobedience, rebellion and defiance, but originally it meant meigen, an act of stringing a bow for purifying evil spirit, devil and disgrace.
